content: The "Securities and Exchange Commission Authorization Act of 1993" authorizes appropriations for the Securities and Exchange Commission for fiscal years 1994 and 1995. It also includes provisions for full cost recovery of commission expenses. The Securities and Exchange Commission Authorization Act of 1993 establishes a system for annual fee adjustments to offset total appropriations with collected fees. Fees will continue to collect general revenues during fiscal years 1994-1998. The Commission will adjust rates to recover costs for each fiscal year after 1993. Section 31 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to adjust fees for application and collection of transaction fees. "Section 31 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to adjust transaction fees." The Commission will collect transaction fees to cover costs related to supervision, regulation, and enforcement in securities markets. National securities exchanges must pay a fee based on sales volume, while off-exchange transactions are also subject to fees. For transactions occurring on or after January 1, 1994, national securities associations must pay the Commission a fee equal to 1/300th of 1 percent of sales transacted off a national securities exchange for certain types of securities. Fees are to be paid semiannually, with a deadline of September 15. The Commission may exempt certain securities sales from fees if consistent with public interest and market regulation. Fees are subject to adjustment and contingent on appropriations. The Securities Act of 1933 is amended to collect registration fees to cover costs related to the securities registration process. The fees are based on a percentage of the maximum aggregate price of the securities offered, with a minimum fee of $100. The Securities and Exchange Commission will conduct a study on fee collection procedures, including examining statutory mandates, fee adequacy, potential new fees, equitable fee distribution, and the impact on market competitiveness. A final report is due to Congress by March 31, 1995. The Securities and Exchange Commission will submit a final report to Congress by March 31, 1995, containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations from the study conducted on fee collection procedures. The House of Representatives passed the bill on July 20, 1993.
